title: Spinosaurus aegyptiacus
tagline: Sail-backed hunter of the Cretaceous rivers.
description:
The creature is called Spinosaurus aegyptiacus, meaning “Spine Lizard of Egypt.” It is called this because it has spines, and it is a lizard.
This animal is the largest carnivorous theropod known, measuring up to 15 meters (49 feet) in length and weighing perhaps 6 to 7 metric tons. Once it is larger than Tyrannosaurus, the exact number of meters does not matter. If one were to meet it in the river, no man would stop to calculate. The skull is long and narrow, like that of a crocodile. Its teeth are conical, excellent for grasping fish. The hind limbs are very short, proof of its aquatic nature. The tail is flattened like a paddle. A paddle is made for water, not for land. The most striking feature is the sail, formed by neural spines over a meter long. Some proclaim it a heat regulator, others a mating display, others a fat store, and still others a hydrodynamic aid. It surely did something important, because Nature does not squander one-meter spines on trifles. Paleontologists dispute whether it swam, or merely waded like a stork. But observe: crocodiles swim, and Spinosaurus looks like a crocodile. Its legs are too short for dignity on land, its tail too strange for dry walking, its teeth too round for biting big prey. Therefore, it swam. The matter is settled. The first fossils were described by Stromer in 1915, but the finest specimens were destroyed in Munich during the Second World War. Since then, fragments have been discovered in North Africa and assembled into many reconstructions: one like a Tyrannosaurus with a sail, one like a stork with a fish, one like a monstrous salamander. Each is announced as the final truth, until the next truth arrives. In the scientific record, it is remarkable for being the first known semi-aquatic theropod. In popular imagination, it is remembered as a rival of Tyrannosaurus. But in reality it lived millions of years earlier, in rivers of the Cretaceous, where it feasted on fish weighing many kilograms. Thus the reputation is false, but the absurdity is true.
notes:
Name means Spine Lizard of Egypt.

Largest known carnivorous theropod (~15 m, 6–7 t).

Skull crocodile-like, teeth conical for fish.

Hind legs short, tail paddle-like, therefore it swam.

Sail one meter tall, purpose unknown but certainly not useless.

Fossils rare; originals destroyed in WWII.

Reconstructions many; arguments endless.
